stories.chapter: Steadfastness in the Face of Hardships
stories.title: Prophet's Journey to Taif
stories.preview: For nine years, since his selection by Allah for His mission, the Prophet (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam) had been delivering the message of Allah in Mecca...
stories.content:
For nine years, since his selection by Allah for His mission, the Prophet (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam) had been delivering the message of Allah in Mecca and making all efforts to guide and reform his community. Excepting a few persons who had either embraced Islam or who helped him though not accepting his creed, all the rest in Mecca left no stone unturned in persecuting and deriding him and his followers.

The Prophet (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam) left for Taif with the hope of winning them over to Islam, thus giving quarter to Muslims from the persecution of the Qureysh, and also establishing a base for the future propagation of Islam. 

Instead of accepting his message, they refused even to listen to him and treated him most contemptuously and rudely. They set the street urchins after him to hiss, to hoot, to jeer at, and to stone him. He was so much pelted at with stones that his whole body was covered with blood.

When he was far out of the town, he prayed to Allah thus:

"O my Allah! To Thee I complain of the feebleness of my strength, of my lack of resources and my being unimportant in the eyes of people. O Most Merciful of all those capable of showing mercy! Thou art the Lord of the weak, and Thou art my own Lord."

The Heavens were moved by the prayer, and Jibrail (Alayhis salaam) appeared with an angel who offered to crush the town between the mountains. The merciful Prophet said:

"Even if these people do not accept Islam, I do hope from Allah that there will be persons from among their progeny who would worship Allah and serve His cause."

Behold the conduct of our noble Prophet (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam)! We get so much irritated over a little trouble or a mere abuse from somebody, yet the Prophet showed such magnanimity.

stories.chapter: Steadfastness in the Face of Hardships
stories.title: Martyrdom of Hadhrat Anas bin Nadhr
stories.preview: Hadhrat Anas bin Nadhr was one of the Sahabah who could not take part in the campaign of Badr. He very much regretted to have missed the honour...
stories.content:
Hadhrat Anas bin Nadhr (Radhiyallaho anho) was one of the Sahabah who could not take part in the campaign of Badr. He very much regretted to have missed the honour of participating in the first and the most illustrious battle for Islam. He longed for a chance wherein he could make amends for Badr.

He did not have to wait for long. The battle of Uhud came about in the following year. He joined the army with the most determined zeal. When the battle took a turn and Muslims suffered a reverse, Hadhrat Anas saw Hadhrat Sa'ad bin Ma'az passing in front of him. He shouted to him:

"O Sa'ad! Where are you going? By Allah! I smell the fragrance of Paradise coming from Mount Uhud."

Saying this, he threw himself into the very thick of the enemy, and fought tooth and nail till he met his martyrdom.

After the battle, it was found that his body had been mauled and mutilated to such an extent that only his sister could identify him, and that barely from the finger tips. No less than eighty wounds of arrows and swords were counted on his body.

Those who strive in the path of Allah with sincerity and devotion taste the pleasures of Paradise even in this world.
stories.lesson: Sincere longing to serve Allah's cause leads to the ultimate success of martyrdom.

stories.chapter: Steadfastness in the Face of Hardships
stories.title: Hadhrat Bilal and his Sufferings
stories.preview: Hadhrat Bilal is one of the best known of the galaxy of Sahabah as muazzin of the Prophet's masjid. He was an Abyssinian slave...
stories.content:
Hadhrat Bilal (Radhiyallaho anho) is one of the best known of the galaxy of Sahabah as muazzin of the Prophet's (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam) masjid. He was an Abyssinian slave of a disbeliever in Mecca. His conversion to Islam was, naturally, not liked by his master and he was, therefore, persecuted mercilessly.

Umayyah bin Khalaf, who was the worst enemy of Islam, would make him lie down on the burning sand at midday and would place a heavy stone on his breast, so that he could not even move a limb. He would then say to him:

"Renounce Islam or swelter and die."

Even under these afflictions, Bilal (Radhiyallaho anho) would exclaim:

"Ahad - The One (Allah). Ahad - The One (Allah)."

He was whipped at night and with the cuts thus received, made to lie on the burning ground during the day to make him either forsake Islam or to die a lingering death from wounds. The torturers would get tired and take turns (Abu Jahl, Umayyah and others) and vie with one another in afflicting more and more painful punishment, but Hadhrat Bilal would not yield.

At last Abu Bakr (Radhiyallaho anho) bought his freedom, and he became a free Muslim.
stories.lesson: True faith cannot be shaken by any amount of physical torture when the heart is connected with Allah.

stories.title: Abu Bakr and the Fear of Allah
stories.preview: Abu Bakr (Radhiyallaho anho), in spite of his being assured of Paradise by the Prophet, was very much afraid of Allah's punishment...
stories.content:
Hadhrat Abu Bakr (Radhiyallaho anho), in spite of his being assured of Paradise by the Prophet (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam), was very much afraid of Allah's punishment. He would often weep in fear of Allah.

It is said about him that he would often hold his tongue and say:

"This is what has brought me to ruin."

and sometimes he would say:

"I wish I were a tree that could be cut and destroyed."

and sometimes:

"I wish I were a blade of grass, whose life ended with the grazing of some beast."

even though he was one of the ten companions promised Paradise. This shows that the closer one gets to Allah, the more one becomes conscious of his own shortcomings.
stories.lesson: True knowledge of Allah leads to increased fear and humility, not arrogance.

stories.title: Feeding the Guest in Darkness
stories.preview: A Sahabi had a guest one night but had very little food at home. He instructed his wife to put out the lamp...
stories.content:
A Sahabi had a guest one night but had very little food at home - only enough for the children. He instructed his wife to put the children to sleep, prepare what little food they had for the guest, and when the food was served, to put out the lamp pretending to set it right.

The plan was that they would sit with the guest, pretending to eat in the darkness while actually going hungry so the guest could eat his fill without feeling embarrassed.

Allah was so pleased with this act of selfless hospitality that He revealed a verse of the Qur'an in their praise:

"And prefer them (the guests) above themselves even though poverty be their lot" (59:9)

The Prophet (Sallallaho alaihe wasallam) said to them the next morning:

"Allah was very pleased with what you did last night."

This shows that true hospitality means putting the comfort of your guest before your own needs.
